linkTarget.anchoringText: The Yu. Korchagin field is located in the Russian sector of the Caspian sea (fig. 1). Distance to the nearest shore (delta of the Volga river) is 120 km. Nearest seaports are located in the city of Astrakhan (175 km) and in Makhachkala, Kizlyar and Derbent. The Yu. Korchagin field is the first field put into operation in the Caspian sea. It was discovered in 2000 by drilling of well No. 1-Shirotnaya, and put into production operation in 2010. Oil and gas content is identified in deposits of lower cretaceous (Albian, Aptian, Neocomian formations), in upper (the Volgian) and in middle Jurassic, Paleoigene deposits.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Overview of the Russian sector in the Northern Caspian

formatted-caption.caption-text: Overview of the Russian sector in the Northern Caspian

linkTarget.anchoringText: The deposit is a thin oil rim clastic reservoir with an average thickness of 20 metres, bounded by a massive gas cap approximately 100 meters in height and an underlying active acquifer (fig.2). The Neocom formation’s GOC and WOC is located at - 1517 m and 1537 m respectively. Effective thickness of the oil rim has considerable gas and water-oil transition zones and is characterized with heterogeneity of filtration properties.

At present the development of the field is close to its completion with 23 production wells. Their arrangement in the oil-saturated horizon is shown on figure 3. The development strategy aimed at high permeability zones of the uppermost Neocomian K1nc (bench 1), oil-saturated in periphery, which contain major geological reserves.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Geological section A-A of Yu. Korchagin field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geological section A-A of Yu. Korchagin field

linkTarget.anchoringText: The application of Black Oil model in simulation of PVT characteristics of oil shows sufficient precision for the performance of engineering calculations. The history matching was done with account of the following correlations: Glaso – for bubble point pressure, solution gas oil ratio, oil formation volume factor; Beal et al – for oil viscosity. The selection of the correlations was based on the minimal values of the correction factors and mean root square deviation (Petex, 2016).Figures 4,5,6.

The application of Black Oil model in simulation of PVT characteristics of oil shows sufficient precision for the performance of engineering calculations. The history matching was done with account of the following correlations: Glaso – for bubble point pressure, solution gas oil ratio, oil formation volume factor; Beal et al – for oil viscosity. The selection of the correlations was based on the minimal values of the correction factors and mean root square deviation (Petex, 2016).Figures 4,5,6.

The application of Black Oil model in simulation of PVT characteristics of oil shows sufficient precision for the performance of engineering calculations. The history matching was done with account of the following correlations: Glaso – for bubble point pressure, solution gas oil ratio, oil formation volume factor; Beal et al – for oil viscosity. The selection of the correlations was based on the minimal values of the correction factors and mean root square deviation (Petex, 2016).Figures 4,5,6.

The trend of reservoir pressure decrease was defined on the basis of analysis of all hydrodynamic surveys of the wells available by the date of the reservoir model creation. About 82 hydrodynamic surveys were analysed (as of September 2016). On the basis of the hydrodynamic surveys the trend of the weighted average pressure decrease was calculated, and material balance equation was aligned with it (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Trend curve of reservoir pressure drop based on the results of the hydrodynamic survey of wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Trend curve of reservoir pressure drop based on the results of the hydrodynamic survey of wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: In material-balance model the deposit’s energy state has been analysed (Figure 8). The analysis has shown that the principal mechanism to maintain the energy of the deposit is the gas cap expansion and gas injection back into the formation, cumulative effect of these mechanisms amounts to about 90% of the deposit energy. This conclusion has shown the necessity to proceed with gas injection.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Correspondence of reservoir pressure decrease with estimated oil reserves. Reservoir simulation results

formatted-caption.caption-text: Correspondence of reservoir pressure decrease with estimated oil reserves. Reservoir simulation results

linkTarget.anchoringText: Each well was analized on the basis of well testing results in steady state for the whole period of well operation (Figure 11)

linkTarget.anchoringText: After definition of equation for each well test, the curve of a,b,c coefficients dependence on gas contact location is built (Figure 12).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 13 shows an example of measurement which is out of the area of physically possible measurements (the area between the curves from Fancher& Brown и Duns&Ross Modified). This measurement cannot be used for history matching of the well model.
